questions.text: Strawberry vagina is seen in:
questions.solution:
Strawberry vagina or angry-looking vagina is seen in case of Trichomonas infection.

Trichomonas vaginitis:

  • Profuse frothy greenish yellow discharge
  • Urinary symptoms
  • Dysuria
  • Dyspareunia
  • Strawberry vagina or angry looking vagina

Saline microscopy -Typical motile flagellated trichomonas seen or motility seen

questions.text: In ovarian cycle increased levels of LH are due to:
questions.solution: • Estrogen has a positive feedback on LH near ovulation and therefore levels of LH are suddenly increased resulting in LH surge.-"With a dramatic increase in estradiol, however, there is a change in the LH feedback. There is initial suppression of LH with low levels of oestradiols. It switches to positive feedback when estradiol levels reach 200 pg/ml. These high estrogen levels also increase the production of more bioactive forms of FSH and LH. This causes the dramatic bio ovulatory LH surge causing a 10 fold increase in LH."

choices.text: Due to interference with blood supply

questions.text: Not true about red degeneration of myomas is:
questions.solution:
Let us see each option one by one.

Red degeneration of fibroid commonly occurs during pregnancy. (Option "a" is correct)

  • The pathogenesis of fibroid is obscure but the initial change appears to be one of subacute necrosis which is presumably due to an interference with its blood supply. Some say that arterial or venous thrombosis is the basis of this and the lesion is the result of infarction. (Option "c" is thus correct).

Red degeneration should be managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics to relieve the pain. (option "d" is thus correct)

  • There is no need for surgical intervention.

questions.text: 30 years old lady with failed medical treatment of uterine polyp, the surgical treatment of uterine polyp can be:
questions.solution:
Endometrial polyp -- Hysteroscopy and resection (best) Removal by ovum forcepIncase of recurrence and, if family completed- uterine curettage hysterectomy

Cervical polyp -- Twisting of the pedicle

Big fibroid in vagina --

  • Removal of polyp by morcellation
  • If associated with inversion enucleate

questions.text: Vaginal epithelium is derived from:
questions.solution:
Development of vagina is composite, partly from the mullerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) and partly from the urogenital sinus.

Vaginal Epithelium

Vagina is lined by stratified squamous epithelium which is composed of the following types of cells:

  • Parabasal/basal cells: Which are predominant when there is no hormonal dominance.
  • Intermediate cells: Which are predominant when there is progesterone predominance, i.e. in luteal phase/latter half of the menstrual cycle.
  • Superficial cells: Which are predominant when there is estrogen predominance, i.e. in follicular phase-first half of the menstrual cycle.
  • The intermediate and superficial cells contain glycogen under the influence of estrogen. In Newborn females, vagina is lined by transitional epithelium.

questions.text: The sequence of development of puberty in girls is:
questions.solution:
Sequence of puberty in girls.

  • G = accelerated growth or growth spurt (1st sign)
  • T = breast budding/Thelarche (1st visible sign of puberty)
  • P = Development of pubic hair-Pubarche
  • H = Increase in height/peak growth velocity attained
  • Menarche = Menstruation
  • On an average, the entire time taken for puberty is 4.6 years.
  • Menarche occurs 2.6 years after onset of puberty.

In males-Sequence of puberty

questions.text: All are de lancey's level 1 support except
questions.solution: De lancey's three level systems of support

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient complains of primary amen- orrhea. She had well developed breast and pub- lic hair but on examination there was absence of uterus and vagina. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• In the question, a 19 year old girl is presenting with primary amenorrhea, she has well developed breast and public hair but on examination uterus and vagina are absent. Since her breast and public hair both are well developed- this means her secondary sexual characteristics are well developed.
  • This means that this female amount of estrogen is adequate, which means she has normally functioning ovaries.
  • Thus, options XYY (presence of Y Chromosome means- gonads are testis), Klienfelter's syndrome (genotype = 47XXY- again since Y chromosome is present, gonads are testes i.e. they are males) are ruled out and in gonadal dysgenesis- gonads are incompletely formed and are streak gonads, M/c example is Turner's syndrome - genotype 45XO. Since gonads are streak, therefore estrogen is insufficient so secondary sexual characteristics are not well developed. In Turners thus by exclusion, our answer is option b- i.e. Mayer Rokitansky kusterhauser syndrome.
  • "Patients with mullerian agenesis, typically present in late adolescence or as young adults, well after menarche was expected, with primary amenorrhea as their only complaint. They exhibit normal, symmetrical breast and public hair development, no usable vagina and have no symptoms or signs of cryptomenorrhea because the rudimentary uterus contains no functional endometrium."

choices.text: In this test fFN is measured from maternal serum
Positive test in first trimester increases risk of abortion
Negative test means delivery will not occur in next 7 days

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the fetal fibronectin (fFN) test?
questions.solution: Fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua. Normally it is found in the cervicovaginal discharge before 22 weeks and again after 37 weeks of pregnancy. Presence of fibronectin in the cervicovaginal discharge between 24 weeks and 34 weeks is a predictor of preterm labor. When the test is negative it reassures that delivery will not occur within the next 7 days.

questions.text: Reason for neurogenic shock in case of uterine inversion:
questions.solution:
In case of inversion shock is extremely profound mainly of neurogenic origin due to

  1. Tension on the nerves due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament,
  2. Pressure on the ovaries as they are dragged with the fundus through the cervical ring and
  3. Peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: OCP's intake causes all Except:
questions.solution:
OCP's have an antiovulatory effect and by virtue of this property, relieve dysmenorrhea (rather than causing it), premenstrual tension and Mittelschmerz syndrome.

Side effects of OCPs are:

Cancers related to OCP use:

  • Carcinoma cervix
  • Hepatic adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma (+/-)
  • Breast cancer (+/-)

Note:

  • OCPs are protective against STDs
  • OCPs are protective against PID

"The risk of hospitalization for PID is reduced by approximately 50-60% but at least 12 months of use are necessary and the protection is limited to current use."

  • At present time, no known association exist between oral contraception and viral sexually transmitted infections.

choices.text: End-to-end anastomosis through an ureteric catheter

questions.text: Ureterovaginal fistula should best be treated by:
questions.solution:
Surgeries for ureteric fistula:

  • Bladder flap procedure (modified Boari-Ocker-Blad)
  • Ureteroneocystostomy
  • Implantation into the bladder

Note: End to end anastomosis may lead to stricture formation.

Colonic transplantation results in recurrent pyelonephritis and hyperchloremic acidosis.

questions.text: Mechanism by which IUD does not act:
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Action Of IUCD:

"The contraceptive action of all IUCD is mainly in the uterine cavity. Ovulation is not affected and the IUD is not an abortifacient. It is currently believed that the mechanism of action for IUCD is the production of an intrauterine environment that is spermicidal."

So, inhibition of ovulation is not the mechanism of action of IUCD. (Except for progesterone containing IUCDs which inhibit ovulation, that too in only 40% cases)

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation with silastic bands

questions.text: Sterilization procedure with maximum chances of reversal is:
questions.solution:
Reversal of tubal ligation

Note: Most suitable for reversal is clips followed by ring, BUT most commonly used for laparoscopic tubal ligation is silastic ring followed by clips

Least suitable for reversal is monopolar cautery followed by bipolar cautery technique.

questions.text: Fetal blood loss in abnormal cord insertion is seen in:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is (A): Vasa previa. In abnormal cord insertion, particularly vasa previa, fetal blood vessels run across or near the internal cervical os. This condition poses a risk of rupture, leading to fetal blood loss during labor. The other options (B): Decidua basalis, (C): Battledore placenta, and (D): Succenturiate placenta, are not specifically associated with the risk of fetal blood loss in the context of abnormal cord insertion.

Normally, the umbilical cord is inserted at the centre of the fetal surface of the placenta.

In velamentous insertion of cord.

questions.text: Best marker of gestational age in 2nd trimester is:
questions.solution:
Ultrasonographic 'fetal measurements' commonly used are

  • T1- Crown Rump length
  • T2-
    • Biparietal diameter
    • Head circumference
    • Abdominal circumference
    • Femur length
  • Best parameter for dating of pregnancy - Measurement of CRL in 1st trimester.
  • Most sensitive parameter for assessment of fetal growth is abdominal circumference
  • Best parameter for assessment of gestation age in the second trimester : Biparietal diameter

questions.text: Banana and lemon sign is seen in which fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Signs of Spina bifida on Ultrasound

  • Frontal bone scalloping or the so-called lemon sign.
  • Elongation and downward displacement of the cerebellum-the so-called banana sign.
  • Effacement or obliteration of the cisterna magna.

questions.text: Immediate cord ligation is done in:
questions.solution:
Also Know:

In case of Rh Negative pregnancy:

No prophylactic ergometrine should be given:

  • Cord should be kept long (2-3cms) to enable exchange transfusion if required.
  • Cord blood sample should be taken from the placental end for:
    • ABO and Rh grouping
    • Direct Coombs test
    • Measurement of serum bilirubin
    • Hemoglobin estimation

Blood smear for presence of immature RBCs.

questions.text: A woman with eclampsia is started on magnesium sulphate. What is the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity?
questions.solution:
Monitoring for magnesium toxicity

  • Urine output should be at least 30 ml/hrQ
  • Deep tendon reflexes(Patellar reflex) should be presentQ
  • Respiration rate should be more than 14/min.Q
  • Pulse oximetry should be ≥ 96%

Remember

Repeat injection are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 ml/hour
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 14/min

If MgSO4 toxicity: Give Calcium Gluconate.

Knee Jerk lost >10meq/l(first sign).

Resp depression >12meq/l.

Resp paralysis >15meq/l.

Cardiac arrest .25meq/l.

"Tips & Tricks"

questions.text: Hormone secreted by placenta is
questions.solution:
FSH & LH are secreted by anterior pituitary.

Leptin is primarily produced by the adipocytes in white adipose tissue.

choices.text: Manual perineal support and maintain the head in deflexion and deliver
Delivery should be conducted in the lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is a recommendation of WHO in the management of the second stage of labor?
questions.solution:
WHO latest guidelines

  • Delivery facilities must offer every woman privacy and allow her to be accompanied by her choice of a supportive person(husband, friend, mother, relative, TBA); all women must be treated with respect.
  • Psychosocial support, education, communication, choice of position, and pharmacological methods appropriately used during the first stage are all useful in relieving pain and distress in the second stage of labor.
  • There should be at least 2 people assisting at every birth, whether it is another health professional, family member, TBA, or village health worker. Arrangements for having another person besides the primary skilled attendant should be planned during the pregnancy.
  • Monitoring of the fetal heart beat must be continued during the second stage to allow early detection of bradycardia.
  • Routine episiotomy is harmful and should not be practiced.
  • Women should not be forced or encouraged to push until they feel an urge to push.
  • Health facilities and skilled attendants should be provided with handheld battery powered or hand-cranked Dopplers for fetal heart auscultation after every contraction. These should be added to lists of essential commodities.
  • Local anesthetic should always be given for any episiotomy, episiotomy/laceration repair or forceps delivery.
  • Provision of critical skills for second stage management needs to be supported by policies as well as training, simulations(drills) and linkage with a functioning referral system.
  • Lack of access to instrumental delivery is a major deficit in obstetric care in many facilities; skills necessary for safe instrumental delivery must be emphasized in preservice and in-service education for all skilled attendants.

questions.text: Most common menstrual complaint in patients of genital TB is
questions.solution:
Menstrual problems occurring in TB patients:

  • M/C menstrual complain oligomenorrhea/Amenorrhea
  • 1st menstrual complain -Menorrhagia (due to Endometritis in acute phase)
  • Pelvic examination - M/C finding = Normal pelvic examination
  • 2nd M/C finding - tenderness present
  • M/C finding in genital TB in adolescent girls - B/L Adnexal mass

questions.text: The commonest cause of occipitoposterior position of fetal head during labour is:
questions.solution:
In vertex presentation when the occiput is placed posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. It is called the occipitoposterior position.

Causes of Occipitoposterior Position:

Most common cause of occipitoposterior position is anthropoid pelvis:

  • In the anthropoid pelvis, the AP diameter of the brim exceeds the transverse diameter. This pelvis is usually of high assimilation type with an extra vertebrae in the sacrum. Therefore, inclination of the pelvis is increased and this favoursoccipitoposterior.
  • In android pelvis the inlet is wedge shaped and so the bulky occiput cannot find space in the narrow forepelvis. This predisposes to occipitoposterior.
  • Primary brachycephaly cause marked deflexion of the head.
  • Attachment of placenta on anterior wall of uterus cause marked deflexion of the head.
  • Abnormal uterine contraction leads to deflexion and persistent occipitoposterior position.
  • At the onset of labor - 15-20% cases are occipitoposterior
  • At the end of labor-5% cases are occipitoposterior
  • M/C position in OP = is Right occiput posterior position.

choices.text: There is no place of wait and watch policy
Dehydration and ketoacidosis should be promptly corrected
Oxytocin has got a definite place in the management

questions.text: The following statements are related to the management of obstructed labour except:
questions.solution:
Management of obstructed labor:

  • Prompt Management of dehydration and ketoacidosis-by giving IV fluids
  • Antibiotics are given to prevent infection
  • Most important step is to relieve obstruction by either instrumental delivery or by doingLSCS. LSCS may even have to be done, if the baby is dead to relieve the obstruction otherwise uterine rupture can occur.

The two main principles in the management of obstructed labor are:

  • Never wait and watch
  • Never use oxytocin

questions.text: Sudden hyperflexion of thigh over abdomen (McRoberts manoeuvre) with the following nerve is commonly involved?
questions.solution:
• McRoberts' manoeuvre consists of forcible abduction of patients legs by sharply flexing them on the abdomen.
  • It is the single most effective manoeuvre and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • McRoberts manoeuvre results in straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebra along with rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head and it decreases the angle of pelvic inclination.
  • Sometimes, overzealous use of McRoberts manoeuvre may result in separation of the maternal pubic symphysis and injury to lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

questions.text: Open neural tube defects are best detected by increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
"Acetylcholinesterase is elevated in most cases of open neural tube defects. It has got better diagnostic value than AFP".

Extra Edge:

'Remember: Amniotic fluid alpha-fetoprotein/acetylcholinesterase determination is a diagnostic test; in contrast to maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein determination, which is a screening test.

questions.text: Appropriate material for antenatal diagnosis of genetic disorders includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Prenatal genetic diagnosis can be made by:

Method

  • Chorionic villus sampling
  • Cordocentesis
  • Amniocentesis

choices.text: Baby is O +ve& DCT is negative

questions.text: A G2P1L1 delivered a baby via full term vaginal delivery. Patient was found to be O negative and her husband's blood group was found to be B positive. She was given anti-d at 28 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the appropriate situation to administer postpartum anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Choice A) Baby is O-positive & Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative - Correct Answer

  • Postpartum anti-D prophylaxis is required only if the baby is Rh-positive to prevent maternal alloimmunization.
  • Since the baby is O-positive and DCT is negative, there is no already established alloimmunization, and anti-D should be given within 72 hours of delivery.

Choice B) All cases, no exception - Incorrect

  • Anti-D is not needed if the baby is Rh-negative because there is no risk of maternal alloimmunization in that case.

Choice C) Baby is O-negative & DCT is positive - Incorrect

  • If the baby is Rh-negative, then anti-D is not required as maternal alloimmunization will not occur.
  • DCT positivity suggests maternal antibodies are already present, making anti-D administration irrelevant.

Choice D) Baby is O-positive & DCT is positive - Incorrect

  • If the DCT is positive, it means maternal anti-D antibodies have already crossed the placenta, suggesting sensitization has occurred.
  • In this case, anti-D prophylaxis is ineffective, as the immune response has already been triggered.

Key takeaway: Postpartum anti-D prophylaxis is required only if the baby is Rh-positive & Direct Coombs Test is negative to prevent maternal alloimmunization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest pelvic diameter at the brim?
questions.solution:
Choice A. Obstetric Conjugate (Correct Answer)

Smallest pelvic diameter at the brim through which the fetal head must pass.

Measurement: Distance from sacral promontory to the thickest point of the pubic symphysis (posterior surface).

Clinical Importance: Determines if the fetus can engage in the pelvis.

Formula: Obstetric conjugate = Diagonal conjugate - 1.5 to 2 cm.

Normal value: ≥ 10 cm (if < 10 cm, suggests cephalopelvic disproportion).

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B. Diagonal Conjugate

Measured clinically via vaginal examination from sacral promontory to the inferior border of the pubic symphysis.

Largest measurable conjugate diameter, but not the true limiting factor for engagement.

Normal value: ~ 11.5-13 cm.

Choice C. True Conjugate (Anatomical conjugate)

Distance from sacral promontory to the upper border of the pubic symphysis.

Not clinically measurable, but can be estimated from the diagonal conjugate.

Normal value: ~11 cm.

Choice D. Anatomical Conjugate

Same as the True Conjugate but often confused in terminology.

Not the smallest diameter at the brim.

Key Takeaway:

The obstetric conjugate is the smallest pelvic diameter at the brim and is critical for fetal head engagement. It is measured from the sacral promontory to the thickest part of the pubic symphysis and is approximately 10 cm. It is smaller than the diagonal conjugate by 1.5-2 cm.
